metadata.title: Elicited sentences
metadata.author: Sonny Davis and Vina Smith
metadata.publication: Unpublished (recorded by Andrew Garrett and Line Mikkelsen on October 25, 2010)

s.note: This use of îin doesn't fit dictionary description regarding personal inflection on following verb.
Glottalization in the personal inflection - hesitation? 3sg/2sg is supposed to trigger 'i-...-ap

s.eng: Do you have lots of cats?
s.note: um after each word; unexpected use of this verb with plural object - WB has tâaraha for have with plural objects
No translation offered; v~m in verb root following WB:G342
v~m in verb root following WB:G342; tih does not condition lengthening of final syllable of stem because stem is vowel final

s.eng: I am looking at the cat eating.

s.note: na- fails to attract acute accent because stem has acute accent of the fixed type (due to VcV shape)
tá sounds more like tu here, but another repetition clearly has tá.
verb can be broken down into: kupa-...-aha 'modal' (G732), vêen 'to pray' (perh. orig. 'to do')

s.eng: I hear the cats fighting outside.
We are talking our Indian language now.
s.note: Could nu be núu = we =4380? arara-chúupha not in dictionary

s.eng: Look the sun is getting up.
s.note: Is "tóo kfuk súpaah" the right parse?
What is tani? What is kunish doing here? Why subordinating pa?
-tih conditions vowel lengthening in the final syllable of verb root and accute accent on that vowel by special progressive accentuation. Why subordinating pa?

s.eng: The bear is growling a lot.
s.note: Why subordinating pa?

s.eng: When I was sleeping I heard something.
s.note: What is nu? Why two inflected verbs in a row? Is it some kind of complex predicate? "I fall down" doesn't really make sense semantically. Could it be "nikik" (a little bit) + something?
Accent on táah, contra dictionary's accent on kúnish in 5511
Accent on táah, contra dictionary's accent on kúnish in 5511
initial ik- of 2240 is somewhat reduced

metadata.title: Elicited sentences
metadata.author: Lucille Albers and Vina Smith
metadata.publication: Unpublished (recorded by Alice Gaby, Andrew Garrett, and Line Mikkelsen on May 1, 2010)

s.eng: I'm going to slap your mouth.

metadata.title: Elicited sentences
metadata.author: Vina Smith
metadata.publication: Unpublished (recorded by Andrew Garrett on September 13, 2010)

paragraph.note: Query is this a possible utterance.

metadata.title: Elicited sentences
metadata.author: Vina Smith
metadata.publication: Unpublished (recorded by Andrew Garrett on September 13, 2010)

metadata.title: Elicited sentences
metadata.author: Vina Smith
metadata.publication: Unpublished (recorded by Andrew Garrett, Line Mikkelsen, and Tammy Stark on January 29, 2011)

s.note: This example does not use the final -at past suffix, at least, it is completely inaudible
Is xuun accented? If so, why? (It shouldn't -- may just be prosodic?) This example uses the final -at past marker

s.eng: What are you going to eat?
When did you eat the potato?
s.note: I couldn't hear person inflection in any of the instances of this sentence.

s.eng: Are you looking at the cat?
You are looking at the cat.

metadata.title: Elicited sentences
metadata.author: Lucille Albers
metadata.publication: Unpublished (recorded by Andrew Garrett and Line Mikkelsen on October 24, 2010)

paragraph.note: pívrihish is not in the dictionary
pívrihish is not in the dictionary

s.eng: I am going to crack acorns
It (acorn meal) is leached free from bitterness

metadata.title: Elicited sentences
metadata.author: Lucille Albers
metadata.publication: Unpublished (recorded by Tamara Alexander on July 23, 2009; © Karuk Tribe)

metadata.title: "How Buzzard Became Bald"
metadata.publication: J. P. Harrington, International Journal of American Linguistics 6 (1930), pp. 125-126, Text 1b

s.eng: Then after Grizzly Bear was already up the hill, again the Ikxareyavs did it.

s.kar:
atipimámvaan
achvúun
xákaan
kun váth eenik .
s.eng: Buzzard and Hookbill had a fight.

s.kar:
" iim
vúra
îin punéekyáreeshara?" atipimámvaan
achvúun
úpeeranik.
s.eng: "You are not going to kill me?" said Buzzard to Hookbill.

s.kar:
xás
achvúun
u piip : "naa iin pukiniikyáreeshara
s.eng: Then Hookbill said: "I am not going to kill you."

s.kar:
vaa
vúra
páy
kyoomahich
nu nísh eesh "
s.eng: This is all that I'm going to do to you."

s.kar:
xás
u eechip
xás
ahíram ak
u yuunkuri
pa mu xvâa .
s.eng: And he picked him up and held his head in the fire place.

s.kar:
achvúun
atipimámvaan
mu xvâa
u kímfiruraa nik .

xás
ú peer anik
achvúun
îin
kun ípeer anik : "xáyfaat ik

i pafyuk.
s.eng: And Hookbill told him: "You must never come around here again.

s.kar:
iim
vúra
pu 'ook
vúrayvu ti heesh ara ."
s.eng: You are not going to come around here."

s.kar:
viri
ta
xanahishich
koovúra
kun ikmuum
achvúun .
s.eng: Then they all pitched on to Hookbill.

s.kar:
xás
kun ipeer " iim
káru
vura
xáyfaat ik ook
i pafyuk.
s.eng: And they told him: "You yourself must not come around here.

s.kar:
iim
káru
vura
pu 'ook
ikr eevish ara ," achvúun
kun ipeer .
s.eng: You too are not going to stay here," they told Hookbill.

s.kar:
xás
achvúun
u piip : " vaa
vúra
ook
kun pakúriihvu ti heesh
nani pakuri

pu 'ook hara
s.eng: Then Hookbill said: "They will be singing my song, no matter if I am not here."
They are still singing Hookbill's song there [in the Amekyaram sweathouse].

text.note: New vocabulary item tachyuunupuk. And ook-ha?

metadata.title: "Swearing"
metadata.author: Julia Starritt
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 142-149, Text With Analysis

s.kar: pa'áraar uum pu'ipítihara pamú'arama múthvuy patu'ívahaak.
s.eng: The Indian did not say his child's name when it died.

s.kar: káru vúra koovúra pamu'áraaras tá kun'ívahaak pu'ipítihara mukun'íthvuy.
s.eng: And when any of his relatives died, he did not say their names.

s.kar: xás hâari tá kunipíthvuuymath míta pakêemish múthvuy.
s.eng: Sometimes they names someone again with the name of the deceased.

s.kar: víriva kári uum tá kunipíti peethvuy, vúra puhúunhara.
s.eng: Then they could still say the name, and no harm was done.

s.kar: xás hâari vúra ára puxútihara, víri vúra tóo piip peethvuy.
s.eng: Sometimes a person just wasn't thinking, so he said the name.

s.kar: púyava tá kunixvíphuunish, xás tá kunváasanha.
s.eng: Then they got angry at him and became his enemies.
Then they spoke to him again.

s.kar: hâari itrôop tu'ûukar káru hâari vúra itráhyar.
s.eng: Sometimes he paid five dollars and sometimes ten.

s.kar: xás hâari vúra uum pa'áraar pahúuntahaak ára vúra tupitaxyárih.
s.eng: Sometimes when a person was peculiar, he "swore" (on purpose).

s.kar: xás patá kunípeerahaak "fâat iyúrish" xás patu'ûurihaak púyava uum hâari ára vaa kúth tóo tháaniv.
s.eng: When they told him to pay something and he refused, then sometimes a person was killed because of it.

s.kar: íkiich káru vúra mutípa káru muxúkam káru vúra akâay vúra pam'áraar.
s.eng: Maybe too it would be his brother or his uncle or any relative of his.

metadata.title: "Coyote's Homecoming" (second telling)
metadata.author: Nettie Reuben
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 168-171, Text 2A

metadata.title: "Coyote Trades Songs"
metadata.author: Nettie Reuben
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 189-190, Text 7

s.eng: uknîi. Coyote thought, "Let me go to Klamath Lakes!"
And he heard it, someone was singing.
And he thought, "His song is really pretty.
I'll say to him, 'Nephew, let's trade!

s.kar: uum káru upakurîihvuti poo'áhootih, "haninuvêe naa hanuvêe naa."
s.eng: He was singing too as he traveled, "haninuvêe naa hanuvêe naa."
He got a long ways upriver.
Somewhere they were sort of singing.
He was going upriver that way.

s.kar: vúra vaa upakurîihvuti uum pamupákurih. "haninuvêe na hanuvêe naa."
s.eng: He was singing his song that way, "haninuvêe naa hanuvêe naa."
And he got a long ways off.
I'll see him when he comes down from upriver."

s.kar: vúra vaa uthítiimti poopakurîihvutih vúra tá ûumukich, "kitâana kitâana îyaa."
s.eng: He heard the singing that way just close by, "kitâana kitâana îyaa."
Suddenly (the person) came down from upriver.
They chatted for a long time.

s.kar: xás pihnêefich upiip, "ishávaas, tá nitápkuup pamipákurih.
s.eng: Then Coyote said, "Nephew, I like your song.
Sing your song, let me learn it!"
So he sang his song, "kitâana kitâana íiyaa."
I'm glad that you gave me your song.
Let me sing my song now."

s.kar: xás pihnêefich kúna uárihish "haninuvêe naa hanuvêe naa.
s.eng: So Coyote sang, "haninuvêe naa hanuvêe naa.

s.kar: xás upiip, "chémi, naa káru yúruk kan'árihrupi."
s.eng: And (the other) said, "All right, and let me go downriver."

s.kar: xás pihnêefich káruk u'árihroov, kahyúras tuvâaram.
s.eng: So Coyote went upriver, he was going to Klamath Lakes.
He got a long way off.
And he got a long ways upriver.
He thought, "I'm really tired of singing.
And he thought, "Let me sing my (own) song again."
But he had forgotten his song.

s.kar: xás patóo kyaavárihvahaak kích tóo piip, "kitâana."
s.eng: And when he tried, he only said, "kitâana."
And he said, "Look, what kind of 'kitâana' is it?
Maybe it's vishváan, maybe it's vishkitâana!"
He went upriver a long ways.
His song had been taken away from him.

s.kar: vaa páy pihnêefich ukúphaanik pa-káruk kahyúras uvâaramutih. kupánakanakana.
s.eng: Coyote did that, when he went upriver to Klamath Lakes. kupánakanakana.

metadata.title: "Coyote Tries to Reach the Sun"
metadata.author: Chester Pepper
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 198-199, Text 12

s.eng: He thought, "The sun is just uphill from here."

s.kar: xás uxútih, "vaa tá káan ukrii, pakúusrah."
pookfúkuvraa, yánava ithyáruk xás tuváruprav pakúusrah.
s.eng: When he climbed up over (the ridge), he saw the sun was rising across (above the next ridge).
In the end he didn't find where it came from.

metadata.title: "Coyote's Gambling Song"
metadata.author: Chester Pepper
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 198-201, Text 13

s.eng: One side beat them (on the other side).
They won all their property from them.
In a little while, suddenly Coyote came.
And he said, "I'm going to sing my song as I shuffle the 'cards'."

s.kar: chavúra koovúra ixráam 'upikyafipáyaachha, pa'ípa kóo kinpáxeepat.
s.eng: Finally he won back all the stakes, as much as they had won away.
He won back the stakes from the gods.

metadata.title: "Coyote As Lawmaker"
metadata.author: Nettie Reuben
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 200-203, Text 15

s.kar: kunpiip, "xâatik ápap yúruk uvuunúpahitih, káru ápap káruk uvuunôovutih.
s.eng: (The gods) said, "Let (the river) flow downstream on one side, and flow upstream on the other side.

s.kar: vaa uum vúra payúruk tá kunvíitrup tuthívruuhrup yúruk.
s.eng: When they traveled downstream by boat, they floated downstream.

s.kar: ithyáruk kúna úpviitrooveesh, uthívruuhrooveesh káru, káruk uvuunôovahiti pa'íshaha.
s.eng: They would travel back upstream on the other side, they would float upstream also, the water was flowing upstream.

s.kar: vaa uum vúra káan ifmaarápiit kamíktaatroovutih, káruk uvítroovutih."
s.eng: Let the new married man push his way upstream there, (when) he is traveling upstream."

s.kar: kári xás kúna kunpiip, "asiktávaan pamukun'átimnam máruk tá kunsánaan.
s.eng: And next they said, "Women carry their burden-baskets uphill.

s.kar: púyava máruk xás áhup sú' tá kunmáhyaan, túr tá kuníkyav.
s.eng: Uphill they put wood in them, they make a basket-load.
Then the women leave for home.

s.kar: kári xás vaa vúra káan tá kun'íitshur pamukúntur."
s.eng: And they leave their basket-loads there."
And then they said, "The basket-loads will walk (home by themselves)."
Let the new married woman be carrying it."

s.kar: kári xás vaa ukupíti payêem, tá pu'áhootihara patur.
s.eng: So now she does that, the basket-load doesn't walk anymore.

metadata.title: "Duck Hawk and His Wife"
metadata.author: Mamie Offield
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), p. 223, Text 27

s.eng: Duck Hawk's wife was Grizzly Bear.

s.kar: kári xás uum vúra hárivaheesh, á'iknêechhan hôoyva tuvâaram, sinmôovishar.
s.eng: So it would be sometimes, Duck Hawk went off somewhere, he was gone a long time.
Then he would come back again.
So once he went away again.

s.kar: kári xás upiip "aaníhich uum chími u'ípakeesh.
s.eng: And he said, "Big brother is going to come back.
He's going to bring home a new wife."

s.kar: kári xás upiip pirishkâarim, "hûut tée piip."
s.eng: And Grizzly Bear said, "How did you say?"

s.kar: xás upíip pirishkâarim, "á' nutákarariheesh, súrukam aah nikyâavish papupasupíichvahaak."
s.eng: Then Grizzly Bear said, "I'll hang you up, I'll make a fire under you if you don't tell."

s.kar: kári xás siit upiip, "aaníhich chími u'ípakeesh, sôomvaan u'ípasukeesh."
s.eng: Then Mouse said, "Big brother is going to come back, he's going to bring home a new wife."

s.kar: kári xás pirishkâarim, pa'îin ta'ítam u'akxáraprupaheen.
s.eng: Then Grizzly Bear scratched the falls (away) downriverward.
You see, the falls were (like) a barrier (reaching) a long ways up.

s.kar: púyava póopvaavruk á'iknêechhan tishravará'iivreen uxus, "hûut áta u'íinati panani'íin.
s.eng: So when Duck Hawk looked down over Etna Mountain, he thought, "I wonder what's wrong with my falls?
Formerly I heard them sounding from here.
So when he got back, he saw it, "My falls have flowed downriver."
And he said, "Who spoiled my falls?"

s.kar: kári xás siit upiip, "naa íp nipasúpiichvat pasôomvaan ti'ípasuk.
s.eng: Then Mouse said, "I revealed that you were bringing home a new wife.

s.kar: víri tá mihrôoha pirishkâarim tutáayvaar pami'íin."
s.eng: Your wife, Grizzly Bear, spoiled your falls."

s.kar: kári xás upiip, "akâay kích vúra ipshansîipreevishan pamu'ípih."
s.eng: And he said, "Who is going to carry away her bones?"

s.kar: kári xás upiip kachakâach "naa ník nipshansîipreevish."
s.eng: Then Blue Jay said, "I'll carry them away."
So she loaded up a burden-basket.
And she carried them to the Bald Hills.

s.kar: kári xás vaa káan xás itháhaas úkyav.
víriva kumá'ii vaa káan kích kun'áraarahitihanik pirishkâarim.
s.eng: For that reason grizzly bears lived only there.
There were no grizzly bears here.

metadata.title: "Blue Jay As Doctor"
metadata.author: Mamie Offield
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 222-225, Text 28

s.eng: Blue Jay pretended to be a 'doctor.'
Then she sucked them (as treatment for their illnesses).
The sick person just got worse.

s.kar: kúkuum tá kunpíshavsip xúrish, athithxuntápan, úus, koovúra kuma'ávaha.
s.eng: They would pay her fee repeatedly with shelled acorns, hazel nuts, pine nuts, all kinds of food.

s.kar: hínupa vúra uum u'apunkôonaatih, kachakâach uum u'apunkôonaatih.
s.eng: There she was bewitching them, Blue Jay herself was bewitching them.

s.kar: púyava patóo xus, "miník kóo ník patá kana'íshavsip," púyava kári xás tu'aráriihkanha.
s.eng: Then when she thought they had paid her enough in fees, then (the patient) would get well.
All the little birds were doing doctor's dances.

s.kar: pakunxútih "kíri nu'áapunma 'hûut kumá’ii pakunyíkihiti" púyava kári xás kunpíkav xánkiit.
s.eng: When they thought, "Let's find out why they are sick," then they summoned Bullhead.
And she said, "Pay my fee with 'áchpuus."
Then in turn they summoned Chipmunk.
And Chipmunk did a doctor's dance.
And Blue Jay sat down there.
She was holding a maul (for driving wedges).
She was going to smash (Chipmunk) with it.
Then Chipmunk said, "You see, it's someone's mischief.
There Blue Jay herself was bewitching them.

s.kar: kachakâach mu'ápuroon kumáheesh hôoyva, ípahak utákararihva, sú' vákay úkrii.
s.eng: You can see Blue Jay's 'devil machine' somewhere, it is hanging on a tree, there's a worm inside.

metadata.title: "The Story of Tan Oak Acorn"
metadata.author: Nettie Reuben
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 226-227, Text 31

s.eng: Mankind was about to come into existence.
They were about to go to a different place.
And they put on their basket-caps.
But Tan Oak Acorn didn’t finish her cap.
So she turned it inside out.
I will be the most important (lit. the highest).
However long Mankind exists, he will eat only me,
(though) the fact is that my cap is a poor cap."

metadata.title: "Eel and Sucker"
metadata.author: Mamie Offield
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 238-239, Text 37

s.kar: chavúra uum koovúra tá kunchífich akráa chamuxich'îin.
s.eng: Finally Sucker won everything from Eel.

s.kar: kári xás upiip páakraah, "nani'ípi tá níxraam."
s.eng: And Eel said, "I'll bet my bones."

s.kar: kári xás vaa káru vúra uchífich.

s.eng: For that reason Eel has no bones.

metadata.title: "The Story of Slug"
metadata.author: Mamie Offield
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 238-239, Text 38

s.eng: All the little wild animals said, "Let's store our food together."

s.kar: kári xás koovúra kuma'ávaha yíchaach kuníkyav.
s.eng: So they gathered all kinds of food.
And they put it all down together.
And they said, "Who will take care of it?"

s.kar: kári xás upíip êeth, "naa ník xuus ni'êethtiheesh."
s.eng: And Slug said, "I'll take care of it."

s.kar: ta'ítam koovúra pakeemishatunvêechas kunikyáviichvunaa, yukún vaa káan kunpávyiihmeesh patupíshyaavpa.
s.eng: So all the little wild animals worked, you see they were going to come back there when it was winter.
So there was a lot, they gathered it.

s.kar: kári xás pakúuk kunpávyiihma axmáy vúra fâatva kunthítiv.
s.eng: And when they came back there, suddenly they heard something.
Then they sneaked up to it one by one.
You see, they were afraid, (they wondered), "What is it?"

s.kar: chavúra kun'áapunma, hínupa êeth, hínupa uxúti, "tátaay, kíri pácheech ni'av."
s.eng: Finally they found out, there it was Slug, there he thought, "There's a lot, let me eat it by myself!"

s.kar: kári xás kunipêer, "mímyaahti, hûutva kóo mímyaahti vúra iim fátaak asasúruk vaa káan i'ifchíkinkutiheesh.
s.eng: And they told him, "In your life, in your whole life you will be sticking to the bottom of a rock there someplace.
You won't be doing anything, either."

metadata.title: "The Boy from 'Itúkkuk"
metadata.author: Nettie Reuben
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 262-267, Text 57

metadata.title: "How the Rube Family Was Named"
metadata.author: Julia Starritt
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 278-281, Text 66

s.eng: A certain Indian once worked for a white man.

s.kar: xás ithâan kuméeshyaav vúra puxích tupáthrih, pa'íshaha tu'uh.
s.eng: And one winter it rained hard, the water rose.

s.kar: xás paapxantínihich upíip "chími kâam vâarami peevapithváram.
s.eng: And the white man said, "Go upriver to the store!

s.kar: sáran sii káru yúfish káru asúxiim káru rope."
s.eng: Go get nails and salt and sugar and rope!"
And he was naming all that they had told him to buy.
And he got to the creek.
He saw that it had risen high.

s.kar: xás ufáathkar, xás vúra kúnish tu'ay, pa'íshaha.
s.eng: Then he waded in, but he was sort of afraid of the water.

s.kar: xás koovúra tupipshinvárihva péethvuy, ípa kunípeerat "ikvan."
s.eng: And he forgot all the names that they had told him to buy.
And he only remembered one thing, "rúup."
So as he went upriver he was saying nothing but "rúup, rúup."
Then he arrived at the store.
And they said to him, "What can we give you?"
And the white man (the storekeeper) said, "Oh, rope!"
And he gave him the rope.
And he said, "I don’t know, I've forgotten."

s.kar: xás payêem vaa vúra mukun'íthvuy rúup.
s.eng: And now (his descendants') name is Rube.

metadata.title: "Elk Hunting"
metadata.author: Nettie Reuben
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 286-287, Text 72

s.eng: The dogs used to herd elk in (to ravines).

s.kar: patóo skákavruk káan xás tá kuníkyar.
s.eng: When (an elk) jumped down over a bank (and disabled itself), then (the dogs) killed it there.
When it was hunting season, they went hunting.
They made hunting medicine, night after night.

s.kar: púyava patusúpaahaak púyava ukráam kúuk tá kunihmárava, tá kunpáatvunaa pa'ávansas.
s.eng: When day came, they went to a pond, the men bathed.

s.kar: kári xás víri pamukunxúskaamhar víriva áak tá kunsímku ánam múuk.
s.eng: Then they heated their bows by the fire, with medicine.

s.kar: kári xás tá kunívyiihship, tá kun'ákunvanva.
s.eng: Then they went off, they went hunting.

s.kar: puvéek vúra uchvánihich tóo krii, tá kunpavyíhish.
s.eng: (The sun) was not yet well out, (when) they got back.
They all carried the elk home.

metadata.title: "Soaking Acorns"
metadata.author: Julia Starritt
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 288-289, Text 75

s.kar: pápiish kunikyâati uum xás tá kunpíishha.
s.eng: When they made píish, they soaked acorns.

s.kar: xás píshiip uum ishahátiimich tá kun'íripkuri su'vári vúra.
s.eng: And first they dug a deep hole at the edge of the water.

s.kar: xás kári vaa paxuntápan káan tá kuniyváykurihva.
s.eng: Then they poured the acorns in there.

s.kar: hâari itroopa'átiv káru vúra hâari kumatêeshich.
s.eng: Sometimes there were five basket-loads and sometimes more.

s.kar: púyava xás kári tá kuníthxup sákriiv vúra ikukatunvêechas múuk.
s.eng: Then they covered it tightly with little logs.
And they put them on with big rocks.

s.kar: púyava vúra káan sú' ukrítumkuri hâari ithahárinay káru hâari kumáxara.
s.eng: So (the acorns) were piled in there, sometimes a year and sometimes longer.

s.kar: púyava patu'amayâahaak xás kári tá kun'av.
s.eng: And when they became good-tasting, then they ate them.
First they strained them with a big tray-basket.
And they poured them in a burden basket.

s.kar: patóo mtúpahaak xás kári tá kun'av.
s.eng: When they were done, they ate them.
They would eat them either warm or cold.

metadata.title: "The Sweathouse"
metadata.author: Julia Starritt
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 288-289, Text 76

s.kar: peekmaháchraam uum yíth ukupeekyâahiti káru peekrívraam uum vúra yith.
s.eng: The sweathouse was made one way and the living-house another.
The sweathouse was dug down into the ground.

s.kar: xás iv'ávahkam vúra ivharatírihshas mûuk uyururâanahitih.
s.eng: And the roof was put up with wide boards.

s.kar: xás ithváaykam pachivchaksurúraam vúra ipshûunkinich pakáan kunvóonkurihvutih.
s.eng: And in front, there was a low door, where they went in.

s.kar: xás vuráakir u'íihya, xás vaa káan pakunvóoruniihvutih.
s.eng: And a ladder stood (there), and they crawled down (into the house) on that.
The ladder was made of a tree.

s.kar: xás iinâak pamu'îirish uum ás upathrívahitih.
s.eng: And inside, their floor was covered with rocks.
And there was a hole in the middle of the floor.
And they made the fire there.
And on the other side, there was also a hole through.

s.kar: patá kunkôohaak iinâak véekrii xás vaa káan tá kunvôonupuk.
s.eng: When they were finished staying inside, then they crawled out there.

s.kar: xás sáruk kúuk tá kun'uum, xás úuth ishkêeshak tá kunpáatva.
s.eng: And they went downhill, and they bathed out in the river.

s.kar: xás patá kunpíkniihvahaak, pá'aah tá kuníkyav, vaa kuníhruuvti tahpus'áptiik.
s.eng: And when they sweated themselves, they made the fire, they used fir boughs.

s.kar: xás vaa imfiráriik tá kuníkya vúra.
s.eng: And they made it a hot place.

s.kar: xás vúra puxích tá kunímchax, xás tá kunástuukha.
s.eng: And it got very hot, and they sweated.

metadata.title: "The Sucking Doctor"
metadata.author: Julia Starritt
metadata.publication: William Bright,The Karok Language (1957), pp. 292-293, Text 80

s.eng: She put her mouth there where the 'pain' (i.e. disease object) was quivering.
And she sucked at it for a little while.
Then she put her hands in her mouth, and she made a lot of phlegm.
She sat on the floor as she did that.
And she spat into her hands, and she held the pain-saliva in her hands.
Then she used the pain (i.e. danced and sang with it).
And when she finished, then she blew the pain away.
Then she did the same thing.
Sometimes she took blood off of the sick person, and sometimes bile.

metadata.title: "Indian Clothes"
metadata.author: Julia Starritt
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 300-301, Text 86

s.eng: The Indian dress was made of buckskin.

s.kar: payáfus uum vúra yítha vúra pufíchmaan.
s.eng: The dress was just one deerskin.
And they were just wrapped in it.
And their apron was made of buckskin.

s.kar: xás pamukunyafusayêepsha vúra uum yâamach ukyâahahitih.
s.eng: And their good dresses were made pretty.
First bear-lily leaves were braided on.

s.kar: axyúus ukyâarahiti káru yuxtháran káru sápruuk ukyâarahitih.
s.eng: It was made with digger-pine nuts and abalone shell and it was made with olivella shells.
The abalone shell was chopped up small.
Their hats were made with hazel twigs and pine-roots.

s.kar: kunikxúrikarati panyúrar káru ikritápkir káru tíiptiip.
s.eng: They were decorated with bear-lily leaves and five-finger fern and chain fern.
And the chain fern was made red.

s.kar: xás pamukun'ápxaan uum uvíkahiti pasárum mûuk káru papanyúrar káru peekritápkir káru patíiptiip.
s.eng: And their hats were woven with the pine-roots and the bear-lily leaves and the five-finger fern and the chain fern.

metadata.title: "A Birthday Party"
metadata.author: Julia Starritt
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 302-303, Text 89

s.eng: Ramona is here making a cake.
Today is her little girl Roberta's birthday.
Later today they will eat her cake.
It will just be them (i.e., the family).

s.kar: puxích kúnish upáthriihtih, víri puxútihap "kíri nupêer paaxíitichas ôo kóova nu'am."
s.eng: It's sort of raining hard, so they don't want to ask the (neighbor's) children to eat here with them.

metadata.title: "Smoke"
metadata.author: Julia Starritt
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 302-303, Text 90

s.eng: There's a big (lot of) smoke just downriver.
I think Herbert is burning fir boughs.
He cut down a tree sometime (recently).

metadata.title: "A Blow-out"
metadata.author: Julia Starritt
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 304-305, Text 91

s.eng: Earlier today I was going around upriver.

s.kar: xás ipvárakirak panini'ahtákni pamuyukúku íp umátnuusat.
s.eng: And on the way back down from upriver, my tire burst.
Ben Wilder is fixing it now.

s.kar: púyava panipkárahaak payêem káru kúna ni'árihroovish, niptakníhareesh.
s.eng: When I go back across-river now, I'll go upriver, I'll go drive back.

metadata.author: Julian Lang and Vina Smith
metadata.publication: Unpublished (recorded by Line Mikkelsen and Tammy Stark on January 30, 2011)

metadata.publication: Unpublished (recorded by Line Mikkelsen and Tammy Stark on January 30, 2011)
